bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 5, 1901

div1.p: Reassures her; date of his return; safety of experiments; difficulties attendant on her visiting; he will return soon, in about five weeks.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 5, 1901
div1.p:
Two
letters, today, from the sweetest,
fattest lady in all the land,
to whom her “Mantee” owes
so many apologies for intimating
or even hinting that her sweet
cuticle shouldd have ever con-
tained the very fanitest trace
of Johannes Barley Corn! Did I,
in the excess of my youthful, 19th
Century fun, lovie, dear, say
that my precious joy had
filled her “outer coat” with
ye dizzy “Tanglefoat”? “Heaving”
forgive me, if I did! for in truth,
fair lady of the sonty “hoof”, I
meant no aspension upon your
fair & spotless integument! Faires
apology I cannot wake!
Well, Well! what has got into my
dumpling day Farmer-lady's
cranium again. One letter
so joyful and cheerful, and the
other “sorter” inclined to “toss
up the sponge”! And all be-
cause Mrs. Sternberg, who does-
n't know what she is talking
about, happened to make a
playful remark! Well, dearest
Heart, how many times have
I told you that you musn't
pay any attention to anything
anybody else says about
my movements! I have already
said that I am coming home
right after the adjournment
of the Pan-American Congress,
and I mean every word of
it! Do you get that through
your sweet “noddle”? If so, just
put it in your pipe and smoke
it! Sunday afternoon- A beau-
tiful, though somewhat windy,
day after a night of hard
rain; but everything looks
so fresh and refreshed. Now,
sweetheart, there are just two
things I want to talk to you
about - one, the question
of the mosquitoes getting
out of our building. In
the first place, they can't
get out. Did you think that
your old mosquito was so
silly as not to take every
precaution against their
escape? How utterly ground-
less such fears are! We
don't forget that a mosqui-
-to “can sit on the edge of a
door”! We don't let him sit
there. Before that door is
opened, I, standing on the
other side of the wire-par-
tition can minutely inspect
this door, which is thorough-
ly shaken before being op-
ened. If when this door was
opened, an insect would
escape, he would find him-
self, or rather herself, in
a small vestibule all lived
with white & protected by
another screen-door, & a man
with a test-tube ready to
tube her at once & put her
back into capacity!. If she got
through the second door, she
would find herself in another
vestibule lived with white
Cheese cloth & protected
by a third screen-door, &
another man with another
tube to catch her! Now
do you see, lovie, dear, that
there is absolutely no
danger of their escape?
Please, therefore, do pray brace
up and don't worry about
any more about loaded
mosquitoes wondereing
around all over our Camp!
If we, didn't take the pre-
caution to see that our
infected insects did not
escape, why what would
one other experiments amount
to? absolutely nothing!
Another thing, sweetheart;
you suggest coming down
on the next Transport for
a short visit. Now nothing
would give me greater
delight and it is a matter
over which I have thought
a good deal- and tried to
think how it could be
done safely & for your
comfort & pleasure. I
wish I could just say,
“Come right along without
hesitating”: but I can't
say so. Firstly, the voyage
would be more than you
could endure in shafe-
rooms that are poorly
heated. At this season, the
Atlantic is so rough that I
dread the voyage home and
think of it as a thing that must
be endured. Therefore if
you conclude to come, we
won't return till the middle
of April, as I couldn't let
you go right back from
Cuba into the cold winter
of the U. S.- If you hadn't been
sick, I would say “alright”,
but I do consider it risky
under the circumstances. If
it wasn't for the $250 of the
Columbian salary that I can
make by returning in February,
I would say come & we will
stay till April or May, but
as it is, I think that I should
come back. Just where or
how I could mess us, I don't
know. Certainly not in
my present mess, for I would-
n't think, for one moment, of
allowing you to join it. It is
simply out of the question.
So that under all of the circum-
stances, I should advise you
not to come, but to wait until
we can arrange a visit at
some later day. If, however,
lovie, dear, you still conclude
to come, write & tell me, and I
will be on hand to give you
the warmest welcome pos-
sible & will do everything to
make your stay happy and pleas-
ant. Think over it carefully
& tell me by return mail
what you will do. I am sorry
that a better boat than the Raw-
lins doesn't leave New York
on the next trip, Jan. 17th,
why does my precious wifie
almost “put her eyes” with
reading without glasses, when
she could be so comfortable
with glasses? Get you a
pair of spectacles, you pretty
thing, & let me see you with
them perched up on your darl-
ing nose! You would look
just as handsome as a
picture! That was a nice
compliment that Beehner
said my precious oomsey!
He knows a pretty woman
when he sees her - of course
he does! I have been over
to the Stark's to dinner to-
night, Sunday, & enjoyed some
broiled spring chicken
so very much, with cu-
-cumbers- Poor sweetheart who
can't eat these things! But
dearest, I really think it very
absurd that you can't eat
all the rice you want- I
don't care if yo there is
lots of starch in it - you
can't live on water and
milk all of your days. Do
pray take a little honest food
once in a while- By the way,
the cake has arrived! Old
mother Greer's very best, and it
is just as nice as it can
be. I am so much obliged to
my precious heart for sending
it to me. I shall “muuch” a
slice of it every night until
it is all gone. It will last
me almost until I am ready
to start home, which wont
be long now - only about 5
weeks, pretty picture- Keep
up your good spirits and
don't forget how to use the
chafing dish, for we must
have some oysters certainly-
some fat, nice, juicy ones!
How is that precious lamb?
and what does she say about
her trip to Annapolis? Did she
almost dance herself to
death? Has she gotten back
to her books again? And her
music? Bless her darling heart
how father wishes to see
his precious girls again!
They have been such good
patient children during
papa's absence. Well, I
hear tattoo sounding and
it is getting to be about
time to “turn in” and take yes
gentle “snooze”. Goodnight, my
precious babies. Wake up
early in the morning, like real
good children. Boo! Boo!!
Monday morning - 7th- Jerusalem!
but I came near oversleeping
myself, and then what would
my sweet Miss Gouty have done
without her letter? I suppose
she would have sat down & cried!
Have you met anybody else,
lovie, dear, who told you all
about how long I would yet
stay in Cuba? Please don't
listen to the idle prating of
every one whom you meet at a
tea. Just put a little confidence
in your Mr Mantee, & you will soon
see him back and fairly crowd-
ing Miss Farmer-lady out of her
beautiful Room! He! He! Ha! Ha!
Love and Kisses & Kisses & love
for my own precious girls.
